DOC.HEAD: Vatican: No Legal Way to Give Noriega to U.S.
With PM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Vatican said today there is no legal way its embassy in Panama can hand over Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega to U.S. authorities. Vatican spokesman Joaquin Navarro also said the Vatican had not discussed with any countries the possibility of arranging exile for Noriega, who turned himself in to the Vatican Embassy in Panama City on Sunday. Navarro told a news conference that Noriega took refuge after the papal nuncio, or ambassador to Panama, agreed to let the ousted dictator stay in the embassy. He arrived there five days after U.S. troops invaded Panama in an effort to capture Noriega and restore the elected government. Asked about U.S. demands that the embassy directly turn over Noriega to U.S. authorities, Navarro said there was no legal way that could be done. He said the embassy is empowered to deal only with the government of Panama and no other foreign government. The Panamanian government has not made any request for Noriega, Navarro added. He said the Vatican and the United States were working together to find a legal solution satisfactory to both sides. ``We're dealing with a complex problem whose various elements cannot be ignored. These elements include legal considerations, diplomatic, humanitarian and therefore ethical ones,'' he said in a statement. Asked about reports of hard feelings between the Vatican and the United States, Navarro said, ``There has been no element at all that could be called a situation of strain, tension, misunderstanding.'' He said meetings between U.S. and Vatican officials on the Noriega case ``have taken place from the beginning in a clear and very cordial climate.'' The comments contrasted with reports from Washington, where a State Department source said Monday that the United States had demanded ``in extraordinarily tough terms'' that the Vatican turn over Noriega to the United States, where he faces drug charges. Earlier this week, Navarro virtually ruled out the possibility Noriega would simply be turned over to U.S. authorities as demanded by the Bush administration. Vatican officials have said Noriega will probably be granted exile in a third country. However, Navarro said the Vatican had not been in contact with any countries about the possibility of offering Noriega exile and said it was too soon to talk about that. Navarro said three other Panamanians arrived at the embassy Sunday with Noriega. He identified them only as a military captain, his wife, and another military official. He said the Holy See believes the matter can be resolved in ``days, not weeks'' but provided no evidence of progress in talks on the fate of the deposed Panamanian strongman.
